title-group.article-title: A strain energy based failure criterion for nonlinear analysis of composite laminates subjected to triaxial loading

article-meta.aff: 2Department of Civil Engineering, The Ohio State University, USA
3Material and Manufacturing Directorate, AFRL, Wright-Patterson, AFB, USA

author-notes.corresp: Tarunjit S Butalia, Department of Civil Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, Ohio 43210, USA Email: butalia.1@osu.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A new strain energy based failure model is developed for fibrous composite laminates under multi-axial loadings, taking into account the effect of hydrostatic stress. A failure mode dependent exponential stiffness reduction model is used to predict material response beyond the initial failure. Predicted mechanical responses and failure envelopes are presented for the 12 benchmark test cases of Part A of the Second World Wide Failure Exercise. The cases cover a wide variety of isotropic, unidirectional and multidirectional laminates under combined in-plane, out-of-plane and triaxial loadings. Both stress–strain curves and the complete failure envelopes were successfully predicted. In some instances, the failure envelopes were open. The predictions together with suitable adjustment of certain parameters are compared with test data in Part B of the Second World Wide Failure Exercise, to be published in Journal of Composite Materials.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The majority of the failure theories for composite laminates are formulated in either stress or strain space. For materials exhibiting nonlinear behavior, a failure theory that includes both the stress and the strain fields would be a more favorable approach, as the entire nonlinear stress–strain response can be included in the failure criteria.1 The strain energy based failure theory originally developed by Sandhu2–5 was modified and extended1,6 as a part of the World Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE).7–9 In this model the energy ratios were defined by dividing longitudinal, transverse, and in-plane shear energy ratios by a material constant. The material constants represented areas under uniaxial stress–strain curves loaded to failure and had dimensions of strain energy. Each energy ratio established in this way corresponds to a potential failure mode. For example, the in-plane shear strain energy of a loaded lamina divided by the total area under a uniaxial shear stress–strain curve at failure is a measure of how close the material is to shear failure. In this formulation the capacity of the orthotropic material to sustain in-plane stresses was measured by summing exponents of the energy ratios. The performance of the theory in failure prediction under in-plane loading condition was generally good compared to the other participating theories.10 However, comparison between model predictions and experimental data highlighted the areas where the model could be improved. Discontinuities observed in 1 - 2 plane (longitudinal-transverse) failure envelope of a unidirectional laminate let to further work by the first author.11 It was shown that that the prediction can be improved by isolating the strain energy induced by interaction between longitudinal and transverse deformation (due to Poisson’s ratio). In the revised failure criterion, this portion of the strain energy appeared as an individual variable in the failure envelope. In addition, a robust post initial failure constitutive model was developed,12 and it was shown to further improve the predictions under in-plane loadings, particularly for angle-ply lay-ups.

The current work is a part of the Second World Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE II), in which a refined strain energy based failure model is developed to predict failure of composite laminates under multiaxial in-plane and out-of-plane loading conditions. There is limited published experimental work exploring the behavior of composite laminates under three-axis loading that can be utilized to establish a new strain energy based failure theory.13–20

sec.title: Lamina analysis
sec.p: In this model each lamina is treated as a homogeneous orthotropic material. An incremental constitutive model is adopted to describe the relationship between stresses and strains. In the proposed formulation, material direction 1 designates the longitudinal direction (along the fibers), material direction 2 is used for the transverse direction (in-plane, normal to fibers), and material direction 3 is assigned to the through-the-thickness direction (out-of-plane, normal to fibers).

sec.title: Constitutive model
sec.p: The material is assumed to be symmetric with respect to the rotation around 1 axis (transversely orthotropic). Although the formulation can be extended to a general orthotropic material, this assumption significantly reduces the need for additional material parameters, while being reasonably realistic. With this assumption the incremental constitutive model is expressed as (1){d>ɛ1d>ɛ2d>ɛ3d>γ23d>γ12d>γ13}=[s11s12s13000s12s22s23000s13s23s33000000s44000000s55000000s66]{d>σ1d>σ2d>σ3d>τ23d>τ12d>τ13}
And the following relationships hold between the compliance coefficients s44=2( s22+s23)s13=s12s33=s22s55=s66
All the instantaneous compliance coefficients can be related to the following instantaneous (tangent) material moduli and Poisson’s ratios21 E1,G13,G23,ν13,ν23

In this model the longitudinal modulus (E1) is assumed to remain constant, while the shear moduli and Poisson’s ratios change as the material deforms. Nonlinear uniaxial stress–strain curves and Poisson’s ratios versus axial strains are mapped using piecewise quadratic interpolation as described in the authors’ previous works.1,12 The interpolation of each uniaxial stress–strain curve expresses the strain as a function of stress. At any given stress, the instantaneous material modulus is calculated by inverting the slope of the spline function. Under a multiaxial loading, G23is calculated at an equivalent shear stress, τS eq, defined in ‘Matrix failure in 1-2' and 1-3' plane (σd=σ1=0). Similarly, G23 is calculated at an equivalent shear stress, τd eq. Compressive and tensile υ12 are expressed as functions of compressive and tensile longitudinal stresses, respectively. Compressive and tensile υ23 are expressed as functions of compressive and tensile mean stress in 2-3 plane (σm), respectively. Unloading and reloading of the material are assumed to be linear with no residual strain after complete unloading (Figure 1). The transverse and through-the-thickness axial moduli are determined as (2)E2=E3=2(1+ν23)G23 Figure 1.
Unloading and reloading paths for a nonlinear stress–strain response.

The through-the-thickness shear response is a model input, while the tensile and compressive transverse responses can be predicted by the model. Based on the information provided by the organizers of the failure exercise,22 the shear modulus G23 and υ23 are assumed to remain constant. From equation (2), this can be seen to result in linear axial stress–strain responses in the transverse and through-the-thickness directions.

sec.title: Strain energy
sec.p:
In order to develop a strain energy based failure model, the total strain energy should be divided up into several components with some physical correspondence. The two major failure modes are matrix and fiber failures and different failure criteria are used to predict each. Matrix failure can take place under axial tensile load, shear stress in 2-3 plane, or shear stress in the longitudinal direction (τ12 and τ13). In all the three cases, the failure plane remains parallel to the fibers (otherwise it is a fiber failure). Therefore, the strain energy in the longitudinal direction (that is mainly stored in the fibers) and the shear strain energies each affect the lamina in a different way. Matrix failure in 2-3 plane is dominated by shear strain energy, while the fiber failure is dominated by the longitudinal strain energy. Since the material was assumed to be symmetric about the material direction 1, the formulation can be simplified by using a transformed coordinate system 1-2'-3', in which τ2'3'=0 (Figure 2). The coordinate axes 1 and 1' coincide, while the rotation angle around 1 axis, θ, is updated at each solution step. In this coordinate system the axial stresses and θ are calculated using equation (3) to (6) (3)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) (4)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) (5)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) (6)τ2'3'=0 Figure 2.
Transformation of lamina coordinate system in 2–3 plane.
The strain energy increment of the material loaded along an arbitrary stress path Γ is (7)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3)
And the total strain energy is obtained by integrating the energy increment along a given loading path (8)Π=∫ΓdΠ
Combining equations (1) and (7), the strain energy increment can be written as

By defining (9)σm=0.5(σ2'+σ3') (10)σd=0.5(σ2'-σ3'), the strain energy increment can be written as (11)dΠ=s11·σ1·d>σ1+2(s22+s23)·σm·d>σm+2(s22-s23)·σd·d>σd+s66(τ12'·d>τ12'+τ13'·d>τ13')+s12(σ1·dσ2'+σ1·dσ3'+σ2'·dσ1+σ3'·dσ1)

Equation (11) can be written in the following form (12)dΠ=dΠf+dΠm+dΠd+dΠS+dΠc where, dΠf=s11·σ1·d>σ1, longitudinal>strain>energy θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3)

The strain energy components can be obtained by integrating each of the strain energy increments defined in equation (12) along the given loading path, Γ. It can be shown that for a linear elastic material, the strain energy components Πf,Πm,Πd,ΠS,andΠc remain stress path independent for any given loading path. As discussed in the previous work,12 energy conservation may impose restrictions on the material moduli and Poisson’s ratios for a nonlinear but elastic material. For such material each component of the strain energy as defined in equation (12), should be only a function of the final stress field and be independent of the loading path. For example loading path independency of Πc for an elastic but nonlinear material under in-plane loading can be shown to impose the following relationship between the Poisson’s ratio and longitudinal and transverse stresses (13)υ12=-c0·E1·eω·σ1·σ2

In the above equation c0 and ω are constants. The material systems studied in this work are considered to be inelastic, so strain energy conservation is not a requirement. If the lamina is loaded in a direction where stress–strain response is nonlinear, and then unloaded (e.g. Figure 1), the area encompassed between the loading and unloading curves represent the energy dissipated during the process. The difference between the total and the reversible strain energies introduces some damage into the virgin material, causing the overall stiffness to reduce. As shown in Figure 1, the residual strain after complete unloading is assumed to be zero, and thus no plastic deformation occurs. No energy absorption is assumed to take place at the interface between the plies. Thus, the total reversible strain energy of a multidirectional laminate is the sum of those of its laminae.

sec.title: Matrix failure in 2'-3' plane (σ1=τ12'=τ13'=0)
sec.p: In this section it is assumed that the lamina is loaded in 2'-3' plane only (σ1=τ12'=τ13'=0, also τ2'3'=0 because of the coordinate transformation). Matrix failure under a general loading case, when all the stress components are nonzero (except τ2'3') will be presented in ‘Failure modes and failure mode interaction’ section. The matrix failure in this plane can take place in shear or tensile modes. In both cases the failure plane is parallel to the fibers. Available experimental observations indicate12–17 that shear resistance of the matrix in 2–3 plane increases with compressive mean stress. The following failure criterion is suggested for shear failure prediction in 2'-3' plane under the action of σm and σd (14)Kd·Πd+m·ad·Πm=1 with m={+1,σm≥0tensile-1,σm<0compressive

In the above formulation Kd and ad are material constants. Suppose that a sample of the material is tested under increasing τ23 until matrix failure occurs (Figure 3). Using the transformed coordinate system 2'-3', in which τ2'3' is zero d>ɛ1'=-d>ɛ2'=(s22-s23)·d>τ23 d>γ23=d>ɛ1'-d>ɛ2'=2(s22-s23)·d>τ23 dΠd=2(s22-s23)·σd·d>σd=τ23·d>γ23 Figure 3.
Stress transformation under pure τ23.

Upon failure: (15)Kd·∫0 γ23 uτ23·d>γ23=1 where τ23 u is the shear stress of the material at failure. The right-hand side of equation (15) can be seen to be the area under uniaxial shear stress–strain curve in 2–3 plane, denoted by Ad. If the material is linear Kd=2G23/(τ23 u)2, otherwise it has to be calculated by numerically integrating the nonlinear stress–strain curve. Thus, equation (14) can be written in the following form (16)ΠdAd+m·αd·ΠmAd=1

Here, Πm is divided by Ad to make the model parameter αd a unit-less constant. This constant, in general, can be different under compressive and tensile stresses. Based on this failure criterion, the shear resistance of the material is increased by compressive σm, and decreased by tensile σm. If the second term of equation (16) becomes larger than one under a tensile σm the matrix will fail in tension (tensile matrix failure). The through-the-thickness shear and tensile energy ratios for the matrix are defined as below (17)rd={ΠdAd(1-m·αd·ΠmAd)if1-m·αd·ΠmAd>00if1-m·αd·ΠmAd≤0 (18)rt={0if1-m·αd·ΠmAd>01if1-m·αd·ΠmAd≤0

Matrix failure in 2'-3' plane is defined by either of rt or rd exceeding unity. Equation (17) corresponds to shear failure mode in 2-3 plane, while equation (18) predicts matrix failure due to tensile stress. In the subsequent sections, these ratios are utilized to define matrix failure under combined loadings. The model parameter αd can be determined using compressive and tensile transverse strengths of the material under zero or a nonzero hydrostatic stress. In this work, uniaxial transverse strengths have been used to determined αd for tensile and compressive σm.
For a general nonlinear material shear modulus in 2'-3' plane is computed using an equivalent shear stress defined below (19)τd eq=σd2·(1-m·αd·ΠmAS)
However, as previously mentioned in this work the shear response in this plane is assumed to be linear.

sec.title: Matrix failure in 1-2' and 1-3' plane (σd=σ1=0)
sec.p: In this section the failure of a lamina under longitudinal shear (τ12' and τ13') is studied. To isolate this failure mode, σd and σ1 are assumed to be zero (also, τ2'3'=0 after the transformation). As previously mentioned, matrix failure under a general loading case, when all the stress components are nonzero will be discussed in ‘Failure modes and failure mode interaction’ section. The matrix failure in 1-2' and 1-3' planes can take place in shear or tensile modes, with failure plane being parallel to the fibers. A similar approach is used for matrix failure prediction under the action of shear deformation in 1-2' and 1-3' planes (20)dγ12'=s66·dτ12' (21)dγ13'=s66·dτ13' (22)dΠS2'=s66·τ12'·dτ12' (23)dΠS3'=s66·τ13'·dτ13' (24)dΠS=dΠs2'+dΠs3'

The longitudinal shear strain energy increment (dΠs) can also be calculated in the material coordinate system 1 - 2 - 3 as: dΠs=s66(τ12·dτ12+τ13·dτ13) because it is independent of θ. The failure criterion for matrix failure in longitudinal shear is (25)ΠSAS+m·αS·ΠmAS=1

In equation (25) AS is the area under uniaxial shear stress shear strain curve in 1 - 2 (or 1-3) plane, and αS is a nondimensional material constant that can be different in compression and tension. The longitudinal shear and tensile energy ratios are defined as (26)rS={ΠSAS(1-m·αS·ΠmAS)if1-m·αS·ΠmAS>00if1-m·αS·ΠmAS≤0 (27)rt={0if1-m·αS·ΠmAS>01if1-m·αS·ΠmAS≤0

Equation 26 predicts matrix failure in longitudinal shear mode. Equation (27) is similar to equation (18), and it predicts matrix failure due to axial tension. Under a combined loading condition, when both Πd and ΠS are nonzero, the matrix is assumed to have been failed if rt from either of equations (18) or (27) becomes unity. Although one may expect that both the equations should predict tensile matrix failure simultaneously, that is αS=αd when σm is tensile, in this work αS and αd are allowed to be different both in compression and tension. An effective shear stress is introduced to calculate shear modulus in 1–3 and 1–2 planes as the material deforms (28)τS eq=τ12'+τ13'1-m·αS·ΠmAS

A piecewise quadratic interpolation3,4 is used to establish the relationship between 1 and 2 plane shear strain–shear stress under uniaxial loading. The shear modulus is the invert of the slope of this curve at τS eq.

Figure 4 presents an example of a double nonlinearity under combined shear and transverse compression. In this example the compressive transverse stress increases shear strength and shear stiffness of the material. The transverse stiffness is calculated by equations (2) and (19), while the shear stiffness in 1–2 plane is calculated using equation (28). Biaxial or multiaxial test data are required to evaluate αS. For example, in-plane shear strength versus transverse stress failure data can be used to determine αS. This material constant is calculated by fitting model predictions to experimental data. The process starts from initial guesses for tensile and compressive αS. Then the failure envelope is calculated and plotted (e.g. shear strength versus transverse stress), and the values are adjusted until a satisfactory agreement is achieved between predicted and experimental failure envelopes. Figure 4.
Double nonlinearity in combined shear and transverse compression.

sec.title: Longitudinal (fiber) failure
sec.p: The available experimental data19 suggest that the longitudinal resistance of the material can be influenced by hydrostatic stress. The following failure criterion is suggested for fiber failure prediction (29)rf={Πf+1·αf·ΠmAf ifσm<0ΠfAf ifσm≥0 1={+1,σ1≥0tensile-1,σ1<0compressive

As indicated by equation (29), the influence of σm on the longitudinal strength is neglected when it is tensile. The material constant αf can be determined so that rf must remains zero under the action of a compressive hydrostatic stress (30)Πf+1·αf·Πm≡0
Equation (30) leads to the following relationship for a material with linear longitudinal and 2-3 plane shear responses. (31)αf=(1+ν23)1-ν23·G23E1
For a general nonlinear material, the initial values of G23, E1, and ν23 can be used in equation (31) as the material was assumed to remain unaffected under hydrostatic stress.

sec.title: Failure modes and failure mode interaction(σd≠0,τ12≠0,τ13≠0,σm≠0,σl≠0)
sec.p:
Matrix failure can occur under tensile failure mode or combined shear failure mode. Table 1 presents a summary of all possible failure modes for a lamina and the associated equations. Table 1.
Summary of the failure criterion and modes for a lamina
Failure Mode Criterion Equation
Matrix Tensile rt=1 σm>0 rt Equations (18), (27)
Through-the-thickness shear (rd)md+(rS)mS+(rf)mf = 1 rd≥rS rd Equation (17)
rS Equation (26)
rf Equation (29)
Longitudinal shear (rd)md+(rS)mS+(rf)mf = 1 rd<rS rd Equation (17)
rS Equation (26)
rf Equation (29)
Fiber Tensile rf=1 σ1≥0 rf Equation (29)
Compressive rf=1 σ1<0
Tensile failure of matrix – Matrix failure is recognized to be tensile failure when rt from either of equations (18) or (27) reaches one (32)rt=1

From equation (32), it can be seen that the tensile strength of the matrix is only a function of the 2–3 plane mean strain energy (Πm). This failure mode does not interact with the other failure modes.

Combined shear failure of matrix – This failure is a result of interaction between axial and shear deformations. The interaction between longitudinal and shear energy ratios is taken into account using the approach proposed by Sandhu1,2 (33)Matrix>Failure>Index=(rd)md+(rS)mS+(rf)mf

The values of rd, rS, and rf are calculated from equations (17), (26), and (29), respectively. The shape factors (exponents md, ms, and mf) as originally suggested by Sandhu were assumed to be equal to one. The authors showed1,6,11 that these values were appropriate for carbon and glass fiber reinforced polymers. Combined shear failure takes place when the matrix failure index from the above equation reaches one. The failure mode is considered to be longitudinal shear if rS>rd, and through-the-thickness shear otherwise. Equation (33) indicates that Πf, Πm, Πd, and ΠS affect the shear strength of matrix. This equation was used in all the 12 test cases examined in this work to predict matrix failure, and it proved to be convenient and effective.
Fiber failure – Fiber failure occurs when rf defined in equation (29) reaches unity (34)rf=1

The value of rf is calculated from equation (29). For a unidirectional laminate, the initial and final failures coincide, and thereby, the failure mode does not influence the mechanical response of the material. For multi-directional laminates the post initial failure response of the failed lamiae is affected by the failure mode. This is discussed in the next section. Equation (34) shows that the longitudinal strength is a function of 2–3 plane mean strain energy and longitudinal strain energy. This failure mode does not interact with the other failure modes.

sec.title: Lamination theory
sec.p: An incremental form of the classical lamination theory is used to calculate strain increments and distribute the applied stresses between the laminae. In this section the formulation is written in the global x-y-z coordinate system. The material direction 3 of each lamina is parallel with the z-axis, while axes 1 and 2 make an angle φ with x- and y-axes. The incremental constitutive relationship in global coordinate system is23 (35)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) where, the stiffness coefficients, Q¯ can be related to instantaneous material moduli and Poisson’s ratios, and the angle φ. Notice that in this formula 1, 2, and 3 subscripts are used instead of x, y, and z for the components of Q¯. The value of dσ3 is known for all the laminae at the beginning of each load step, as it is assumed to be the same for all the laminae, and equal to dσz. Given a dσz, the above equations can be rearranged as follows (36)dɛz=1Q¯33(dσz-Q¯13·dɛx-Q¯23·dɛy-Q¯36·dγxy)
Therefore dɛz can be eliminated by combining equations (35) and (36) θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) or (37)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3)
Similarly (38)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3) (39)θ=12tan-1(τ23σ2-σ3)

Equations (37), (38) and (39) can be written in matrix form (40){dσxdσydτxy}=[Q∧]·{dɛxdɛydγxy}+[R]·dσz where (41)Q∧11=Q¯11-Q¯13·Q¯31Q¯33,R1=Q¯13Q¯33 and so on. Using and approach similar to that of classical lamination theory, the incremental constitutive relationship for a multidirectional laminate consisting of N layers can be written as (42){[N][M]}=[[A][B][B][D]]·{[ɛ0][κ]}+σz{{c}{e}} with (43)Aij=∑k=1 N[Q∧ij]k·tk (44)Bij=12∑k=1 N[Q∧ij]k·(zk 2-zk-1 2) (45)Dij=13∑k=1 N[Q∧ij]k·(zk 3-zk-1 3) (46)ci=∑k=1 N[Ri]k·tk (47)ei=12∑k=1 N[Ri]k·(zk 2-zk-1 2) (48){NxNyNxy}=∫-h/2 h/2σ¯·dz (49){MxMyMxy}=∫-h/2 h/2z·σ¯·dz also (50)tk=zk+1-zk (51)h=∑k=1 Ntk

In the above formulation the z-axis is in the laminate plane and z = 0 on the midplane. The x- and y-axes are in the plane of the laminate, and the orientation angle of each lamina is the angle that its material direction 1 makes with the global x-direction.

sec.title: Post initial failure behavior
sec.p: The post initial failure behavior of a lamina depends on the failure mode. The first fiber failure in any of the laminae is assumed to be the final failure of the laminate. Although in some cases the laminate can sustain additional stresses after the first fiber failure, the increase in strength is typically insignificant12 for the types of loading considered here. When matrix failure in combined shear loading is predicted, G12 and G23 are decreased exponentially, according to the following rules (52)G12 r=G12·exp[-kS(|γ12|+|γ13|-|γ12 Y|-|γ13 Y|)] (53)G23 r=G23·exp[-kd(|γd|-|γd Y|)]

Here, superscript r refers to the reduced shear modulus after initial failure, superscript Y denotes strain level at which the failure has occurred, and kS and kd are reduction factors. The reduction factors can be evaluated experimentally by testing multiaxial laminates and γd is computed by integrating (54)γd=∫Γdλd (55)d>λd=2(s22-s23)·d>σd

Based on previous work,12 the suggested range for kS is between 15 and 50 and that for kd is between 100 and 200. When the matrix failure mode is tensile, all the moduli except the longitudinal modulus are set to zero. The longitudinal modulus remains unchanged after matrix failure (Table 2). Table 2.
Post initial failure moduli of a lamina
Mode E1 G23 G12 υ13 υ23
Fiber failure 0 0 0 0.5 0.5
Tensile matrix failure Unchanged 0 0 Unchanged Unchanged
Combined shear Unchanged Exponential reduction Exponential reduction Unchanged Unchanged

sec.title: Solution scheme
sec.p:
A computer program was developed to implement the model and analyze the test cases of Table 3. The program uses an explicit incremental solution scheme to predict mechanical response and failure of a laminate. The load is applied incrementally to the laminate, and equation (42) is solved by Gauss elimination method to calculate strain increments. The strain increments are transformed into local coordinate system of each lamina. The transformed strain increments are imposed on each lamina and the corresponding stress increments are calculated. The failure of each lamina and associated failure mode is assessed at each step (Table 1). The stress increments from all the lamiae are transformed to the global coordinate system and are integrated through the thickness to compute a load increment. This load increment is subtracted from the applied load increment to calculate a residual (error) load vector. Table 3.
Laminate lay-up, material types, and loading cases for WWFE-II (Kaddour and Hinton22)
Case Lay-up Material system Loading case
1 Resin MY750 epoxy σx versus σz failure envelope with σy=σz
2 0° T300/PR319 τ12 versus σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3
3 0° T300/PR319 γ12 versus σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3
4a 0° T300/PR319 Shear stress–strain curve (τ12-γ12) with σ1=σ2=σ3=-600MPa
5 90° E-glass/MY750 epoxy σ2 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ1=σ3
6 0° S-glass/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3
7 0° A-S carbon/epoxy σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3
8 (+35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy σy versus σz failure envelope with σx=σz
9b (+35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy Stress–strain curves (σy-ɛx and σy-ɛy) at σz=σx=-100MPa
10 (45deg/-45deg/90deg/0deg)S IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz failure envelope with σy=σx=0
11 (90deg/0deg)2S IM7/8551-7 τyz versus σz failure envelope with σy=σx=0
12 (90deg/0deg)2S IM7/8551-7 Stress–strain curves (σz-ɛz, σz-ɛx, and σz-ɛy) for σy=σx=0
a
σ1=σ2=σ3=-600MPa is applied first, followed by the shear loading until failure. b
σ1=σ2=σ3=-100MPa is applied first and the resulting strain values are recorded. Then compressive σy is increased gradually until failure.

If the magnitude of the residual vector becomes greater than a given maximum acceptable error (input) a warning message is generated, suggesting the user to decrease load increment size. The laminate stiffness matrix is updated at each load increment using equations (41) and (43) to (49). For those laminae that have experienced matrix failure, equations (52) and (53) are utilized to decrease the stiffness. Final failure is defined as either the first fiber failure or a diagonal member of the laminate’s stiffness matrix, defined in equation (42), becoming very small (‘very small’ is defined as a diagonal member reducing to 10-8 times its initial value). The diagonal members of the stiffness matrix reduce to very small values as a result of matrix failure of some or all of the laminae (usually the latter) in shear or tensile modes. Therefore, the final failure mode can be fiber failure if one or more laminae undergo fiber failure (equation (34)), tensile failure if most of the lamina experience tensile failure of the matrix (equation (32)), or shear failure if most of the lamina experience combined shear failure (equation (33)). The final failure modes of a multidirectional laminate that are distinguished by this model are presented in Table 4. Table 4.
Modes of final failure for a multidirectional laminate
Failure Mode Description
Matrix Tensile failure A diagonal member of stiffness matrix becomes very small after matrix failure of some of the laminae, mostly in tensile mode.
Shear failure A diagonal member of stiffness matrix becomes very small after matrix failure of some of the laminae, mostly in combined shear mode.
Fiber Tensile First tensile fiber failure
Compressive First compressive fiber failure

sec.title: Laminate failure prediction
sec.p: The failure model described previously is used to analyze the 12 cases of the WWFE-II.22 The loading cases and material systems are summarized in Table 3. Case 1 is a neat epoxy resin under multiaxial loading. Cases 2 to 7 are unidirectional laminates under multidirectional loadings. For these cases the predictions are presented in 1 - 2 - 3 coordinate system that coincides with the material directions of the laminae. The remaining cases are multidirectional laminates under multidirectional loadings. The effect of thermal residual stresses that develop during curing of multidirectional laminates has not been included in the numerical failure predictions.

sec.title: Case 1: Failure envelope for MY750 epoxy resin
sec.p: The failure envelope of an unreinforced MY750 epoxy resin is obtained in σx-σy plane with σz=σy. The strain energy theory was originally developed for failure prediction of fiber-based composites and thus some modifications are needed in the formulation before it can be applied to isotropic materials such as the neat epoxy specimen for Case 1. The hydrostatic and distortional strain energies Πm and Πd are computed based on the mean and deviator stresses24 (56)σmi=(σ1+σ2+σ3)/3 (57)dɛmi=dɛ1+dɛ2+dɛ3 (58)σdi=(σ1-σ2)2+(σ1-σ3)2+(σ2-σ3)22 (59)dɛdi=132[(dɛ1-dɛ2)2+(dɛ2-dɛ3)2+(dɛ1-dɛ3)2]

The directions 1, 2, and 3 are the principle stress directions, which coincide with the x, y, and z directions for this particular loading case. Equations (56) and (57) are used to compute mean stress and the corresponding volumetric strain increment. Equations (58) and (59) are used to compute deviator stress and strain increment. Strain energy increments dΠmi and dΠdi are calculated by multiplying each stress by the corresponding strain increment. The values of σmi and σdi from the above equations can be seen to be different than those from equations (9) and (10). Since the matrix is isotropic the plane of shear failure can no longer be assumed to be parallel to 1 axis, and the three major stresses contribute equally in failure. Therefore, the equations are modified to take this into account by using isotropic mean and deviator stresses. Equations (17) and (18) are used to predict tensile and shear failures. The material is assumed to behave linearly, with the elastic constants furnished by the organizers of the failure exercise. Material constant αd was back-calculated to be 1.636 using the given compressive strength of 120 MPa. With this value for αd the tensile strength is predicted to be 73 MPa that is close to (and on the conservative side of) the given value of 80 MPa. Therefore, a single value of 1.636 for αm was used for both tension and compression. This failure criterion has some similarities to the one proposed by Hu and Pae25 for isotropic material subject to hydrostatic pressure.

Figure 5 presents the predicted failure envelope. The envelope can be seen to be open in the third quadrant, as the stress state gets close to the compressive hydrostatic stress of σx=σy=σz. The predicted strength of the resin under tensile hydrostatic stress is σx=σy=σz=62MPa, and the predicted uniaxial tensile strength is 73MPa. Under σx=0 the tensile and compressive strengths of the material (σx=σz) are 57.6 and 151 MPa, respectively. Figure 5.
Predicted σx versus σz failure envelope for MY750 epoxy resin (σy=σz).

sec.title: Case 2: τ12 versus σ2 failure envelope for UD T300/PR319 with σ1=σ2=σ3
sec.p:
For Case 2 the failure envelope of τ12 versus uniform hydrostatic stress is obtained for a unidirectional T300/epoxy laminate. The material properties and uniaxial stress–strain curves for T300/PR319 given by the organizers of the failure exercise22 were used as input to the model. Through-the-thickness shear behavior is assumed to be linear because the actual stress–strain data have not been provided. Furthermore, the assumption of symmetry with respect to rotation around axis 1 can be seen to be valid for this material, as the transverse and through-the-thickness moduli and strengths are identical. The compressive and tensile values of αd which were back calculated from the measured tensile and compressive transverse strengths were determined to be 10 and 1.8, respectively. Figure 6 presents the predicted and measured transverse and longitudinal strains versus transverse compressive stress. The predicted and measured longitudinal strengths are in agreement. The predicted transverse strains are linear, as G23 was assumed to be constant, while the measured curve shows some nonlinearity. Tensile and compressive values of 2 and 1 are suggested for αS, based on previous experience of the authors with similar materials.12 Using the relationship presented in equation (31), the value of αf is calculated to be 0.042. Figure 6.
Predicted versus measured stress–strain curves under uniaxial transverse stress.

Each data point of the failure envelope is obtained by proportionally loading the material under combined hydrostatic stress and in-plane shear stress until failure. For all the test cases with a unidirectional lay-up studied herein, including this case, the analysis was stopped upon the first failure (whether be fiber or matrix failure). Equations (18), (26), (27), (32), and (33) were used to predict matrix failure and determine the failure modes. Figure 7 shows the predicted failure envelopes for this loading case, using two values of 0 and 0.042 for αf. The failure envelope using a value of 0.042 for αf is an open envelope in the second quadrant. That is, the material will not fail under compressive hydrostatic stress. The model predicts that as the hydrostatic stress increases the shear strength becomes asymptotic to approximately 320 MPa. Also presented in the figure, is the predicted failure envelope when αf=0. For αf=0, in the second quadrant the in-plane shear strength increases with the hydrostatic stress. When αf is calculated from equation (31), rf remains zero under any level of compressive hydrostatic stress and the in-plane shear strength increases with compressive hydrostatic stress. As a result, the material does not fail under a range of shear to hydrostatic stress ratios, as seen in the figure. With αf=0, the hydrostatic stress can cause fiber failure when the compressive stress reaches the longitudinal compressive strength of 950 MPa, resulting in a closed failure envelope. This envelope is presented only for comparison purposes to demonstrate the effect of αf. The two envelopes are nearly the same in the first quadrant and the second quadrant up to the compressive hydrostatic stress of about 250 MPa, and they gradually deviate as the compressive hydrostatic stress increases. From equation (29) it can be seen that higher values of αf result in lower values of rf under a compressive hydrostatic stress, and thereby higher shear strengths. With αf=0 the failure envelope is not open and material strength under hydrostatic compressive stress is about 950 MPa. A value of αf between 0 and 0.042 will result in a closed failure envelope that lies between the two envelopes that are presented in the figure. Figure 7.
τ12 versus σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3 for unidirectional T300/PR319 laminate.

sec.title: Case 3: γ12 versus σ2 failure envelope for UD T300/PR319 with σ1=σ2=σ3
sec.p:
For Case 3 in-plane shear strain versus hydrostatic stress failure envelope was obtained for the same material and loading conditions presented in Case 2. The results are plotted in Figure 8 for the two values of zero and 0.042 for αf. As was observed in the Case 2 discussion for in-plane shear strength during compressive hydrostatic stress the failure envelope is open. Figure 8.
γ12 versus σ2 failure envelope with σ1=σ2=σ3 for unidirectional T300/PR319 laminate. Figure 9.
In-plane shear stress–strain curve for a unidirectional T300/PR319 laminate under superimposed hydrostatic stresses.

sec.title: Case 4: In-plane shear stress–strain curve for UD T300/PR319 laminate under a superimposed hydrostatic stress of −600 MPa
sec.p: For Case 4 the in-plane shear stress–strain response of a unidirectional T300/PR319 laminate is predicted for σ1=σ2=σ3=-600MPa. The model parameters used for the analysis are the same as those for the Cases 2 and 3. In this case, the compressive hydrostatic stress of up to 600 MPa was applied first, then the laminate was loaded in in-plane shear stress until failure and the shear stress–strain curve was plotted. The failure mode was longitudinal shear failure of the matrix. Equations (26) and (33) were used to predict the failure under this loading condition. Equation (28) was used to calculate the increase in the shear modulus due to the compressive hydrostatic stress, and equation (18) was used to compute the stress–stress responses. Depicted in Figure 9 are three stress–strain curves obtained under superimposed compressive hydrostatic stresses of 0, 200, and 600 MPa. The two additional curves (under 0 and 200 MPa) are presented for comparison. It is apparent that the shear strength and failure shear strain of the material increases with compressive hydrostatic stress. The longitudinal and transverse (or through-the-thickness) strains under the hydrostatic stress of 600 MPa and zero shear stress are predicted to be −0.17% and −1.65%, respectively. The in-plane shear strength and corresponding shear failure strain are predicted to be 233 MPa and 19%, respectively.

sec.title: Case 5: σ2 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ1=σ3 for UD E-glass/MY750 epoxy
sec.p:
For Case 5 σ2 versus σ3 (while σ1=σ3) failure envelope is developed for a unidirectional E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate. The material properties and uniaxial stress–strain curves for this material system are provided in the guidelines for the failure exercise.22 Through-the-thickness shear behavior is assumed to be linear. Using the given values of tensile and compressive transverse strengths, the compressive and tensile values of αd were back-calculated to be 9 and 1.5, respectively. Depicted in Figure 10 are the predicted failure envelopes using αf=0.29 (as determined from equation (31)) and αf=0. For αf=0.29 the material does not fail under any uniform compression (σ1=σ2=σ3), and the failure envelope is open in the third quadrant. The strength of the material in uniform tension (σ1=σ2=σ3) is 26 MPa. The failure mode for the section of the failure envelope in the first quadrant between the two dashed lines (slopes are 0.68 and 1.2) is tensile, and for the rest of the envelope it is combined shear. With σ1=σ3 and σ2=0 the tensile and compressive strengths are 42 and 148 MPa, respectively. With αf=0 failure in compression occurs even when conditions are hydrostatic, underscoring the importance of a proper methodology for evaluating αf. Figure 10.
σ2 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ1=σ3 for unidirectional E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate.

sec.title: Case 6: σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3 for UD S-glass/epoxy
sec.p:
For Case 6 σ1 versus σ3 (σ2=σ3) failure envelope is developed for a unidirectional S2-glass/epoxy 2 laminate. The model parameters for this material system are determined to be αd=0.6 in tension and 8.5 in compression, and αf=0.32. Since, the transverse and through-the-thickness tensile strengths are not equal (63 MPa versus 50 MPa), the average value of 56 MPa was used to determine the tensile αd. Figure 11 shows the predicted σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope for σ2=σ3. Under this loading condition σd is always equal to zero (because σ2=σ3) so the matrix is not subjected to failure under shear (shear stress in 1-2 and 1-3 planes are zero as well). Thus, matrix failure can only take place in tensile mode when σ2>0 (first and second quadrants). In the third and fourth quadrants (σ2<0) only fiber failure can take place. As can be seen, the failure strength in the first and second quadrants is unaffected by variations in the longitudinal stress. The failure modes along the horizontal part of the failure envelope in the first and second quadrants are tensile failure of the matrix. The failure mode along this section of the envelope was predicted by equations (18) and (27). The tensile strength of the matrix under σ2=σ3 is predicted to be 45 MPa. The failure mode in the third quadrants is compressive fiber failure and that in the fourth quadrant is tensile fiber failure. In the third quadrant the longitudinal compressive strength increases with σ2 (σm=σ2). As the failure envelope approaches σ1=σ2(=σ3) line from the left side the strength grows unboundedly because with the value of αf computed from equation (31) fiber strength is infinite under a hydrostatic compressive loading. Moreover, the failure envelope is open between σ1=σ2 line in the third quadrant and the negative side of the vertical axis, because in this region the longitudinal stress is compressive and less than σm in magnitude. In the fourth quadrant the longitudinal tensile strength decreases with compressive σ2. The predicted longitudinal tensile strength at σ2=σ3=1699MPa is almost zero (right side of the compressive vertical axis). Figure 11.
σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3 for a unidirectional S-glass/epoxy laminate.

sec.title: Case 7: σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3 for UD A-S carbon/epoxy
sec.p:
For Case 7 σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2=σ3) failure envelope is obtained for a unidirectional A-S carbon/epoxy laminate. Using a similar approach as before, the model parameters are evaluated as αd=11 in tension and 2 in compression, and αf=0.0585. The loading conditions for this case are similar to the loading conditions for Case 6. The predicted failure envelope, presented in Figure 12, has the same characteristics as the one presented for Case 6. The tensile strength of the matrix under σ2=σ3 is predicted to be 24 MPa. The failure envelope is open in the third quadrant between the vertical axis and σ2=σ1 line. The compressive transverse and through-the-thickness stresses that result in zero tensile longitudinal strength is 1990 MPa. Figure 12.
σ1 versus σ3 failure envelope with σ2=σ3 for a unidirectional A-S carbon/epoxy laminate.

sec.title: Case 8: σy versus σz failure envelope with σx=σz for a (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate
sec.p: Case 8 is the first multidirectional laminate that is studied herein. For this case σy versus σz (σx=σz) failure envelope is presented for a (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate. The post initial failure model parameters kS and kd, as well as αS are selected based on the previous work12 and they are: kd=150 kS=50 αS=2for>tensileσm αS=1for>compressiveσm

To obtained the failure envelope, the material was loaded proportionally for values of σy/σz (with σx=σz) ranging from zero to ±∞ until the final failure. The stresses at which the initial and final failures occurred were recorded for each loading proportion. Figure 13 shows the predicted initial and final failure envelopes. In a small section in the first quadrant, where the initial failure model is tensile failure of the matrix, the initial and final failures essentially coincide. This is because after the tensile failure, shear moduli of all the failed laminae (which in this case includes all the laminae) are reduced to zero, causing an unstable stiffness matrix. The initial failure mode is mostly combined shear failure over the rest of the failure envelope. The final failure throughout the failure envelope is due to instability of the stiffness matrix as the material moduli are gradually reduced using the exponential model. Both the initial and final failure envelopes are open in the third quadrant, indicating very high predicted strengths under such loading conditions. Figure 14 presents typical stress strain curves for a stress ratio of σy/σz=-20/3. The curves demonstrate the rate of stiffness reduction up to the point where the slops become virtually zero. Figure 13.
σy versus σz failure envelope with σx=σz for a (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate. Figure 14.
Axial strains versus σy for a (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate under the loading conditions of Case 8 with the stress ratio of σy/σz=-20/3.

sec.title: Case 9: Axial stress–strain curves for (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate at σz=σx=-100MPa
sec.p:
For Case 9 σy versus εx and εy stress–strain curves are obtained for (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate at σz=σx=-100MPa. The material system and lay-up for this loading case are the same as those of Case 8, and the same material and model parameters are used in the analysis. The laminate is first loaded to σx=σy=σz=-100MPa, then compressive σy is increased beyond 100 MPa until final failure takes place. Depicted in Figure 15 are the predicted stress–strain curves for this loading case. Predicted values of εx, εy, and εz at σx=σy=σz=-100 MPa are −0.12%, −0.22%, and −0.35%, respectively. The figure presents the stress–strain curves both before and after this point. The initial failure is predicted to occur at σy=-339 MPa (with σz=σx=-100 MPa ). At this stress state all the laminae fail under through-the-thickness shear failure mode (combined shear failure with rd>rS). At initial failure εx, εy, and εz are predicted to be 0.92%, −2.41%, and 0.15%, respectively. The final failure is predicted at σy=-414MPa. The stress–strain curves exhibit some nonlinearity before the initial failure and strong nonlinearity between initial and final failures. No fiber failure is predicted under this loading condition. Figure 15.
σy-ɛx and σy-ɛy stress strain curves at σz=σx=-100MPa for (35deg/-35deg)2S E-glass/MY750 epoxy laminate.

sec.title: Case 10: τyz versus σz failure envelope for (45deg/-45deg/90deg/0deg/)S IM7/8551-7 laminate
sec.p: For Case 10 τxy versus σz failure envelope is predicted for a (45deg/-45deg/90deg/0deg)Squasi-isotropic IM7/8551-7 laminate. Unlike the cases studied previously, in this loading case the out-of-the-plane shear stress (τyz) is nonzero. The shear strain γyz is assumed to be constant across the thickness of the material, and the applied shear stress is distributed between the laminae proportional to y-z shear stiffness of each lamina. The model parameters for IM7/8551-7 material system are determined using the methods explained before and they are listed below αd=3.5for>tensileσmαd=3for>compressiveσmαf=0.05kd=100kS=20αS=2for>tensileσmαS=1for>compressiveσm

The tensile αd is determined based on the average of tensile transverse and through-the-thickness strengths. The predicted initial and final failure envelopes are presented in Figure 16. The initial failure under pure tensile and compressive through-the-thickness stresses takes place at σz=66.1MPa and -572MPa, respectively. Although the applied stress is along z direction, it induces equal and opposite stresses along the local 1 and 2 directions of each lamina, causing the matrix to fail in through-the-thickness shear mode (equation (33)). For example, upon initial failure under σz=-572 MPa, the model predicts σ1=-σ2= 251 MPa for all the laminae. These internal axial stresses are induced in the material because the layers are orthotropic (different values of ν13 and ν23). The final failures under tensile and compressive σz were predicted to occur at 73.4 and 673 MPa, respectively. Under pure τyz the initial and final failures occur at 67.8 and 111 MPa, respectively. At τyz=67.8 MPa the 0° laminae undergo through-the-thickness shear failure, followed by through-the-thickness shear failure of ±45∘ laminae at 77 MPa. The 90° laminae fail under longitudinal shear mode at 97 MPa. Upon matrix failures of each lamina, the shear stiffness reduction of the affected laminae begins according to equations (52) and (53). After matrix failure of the last laminae the overall stiffness of the laminate begins to reduce rapidly, leading to the final failure at 111 MPa. The final failure modes are marked on the figure. Figure 16.
τyz versus σx failure envelope for (45deg/-45deg/90deg/0deg)S IM7/8551-7 laminate.

sec.title: Case 11: τyz versus σz stress–strain curves for (90deg/0deg)2S IM7/8551-7 laminate
sec.p: For Case 11 τyz versus σz failure envelope is predicted for a (90deg/0deg)2Slaminate made of IM7/8551-7 material system. The model parameters are the same as those from Case 10. As before, the out-of-plane shear stress is distributed between the laminae proportional to their corresponding shear stiffnesses.

Figure 17 presents the initial and final failure envelopes predicted by the model. The predicted initial failure when pure σz is applied to the laminate is 66.1 MPa for tension and 572 MPa for compression, and the final strengths are 73.4 and 673 MPa, respectively (stress–strain response under compressive σz is studied in the next section). The predicted initial and final failures under pure τyz are 63.6 and 98.9 MPa, respectively. Under pure τyz the initial failure was predicted to be through-the-thickness shear failure of 0° laminae. At shear stress of 87 MPa the 90° laminae were predicted to fail in longitudinal shear mode. Figure 17.
τyz versus σx failure envelope for (90deg/0deg)2s IM7/8551-7 laminate.

From Figures 16 and 17 it can be seen that the failure envelopes for this case and Case 10 are very similar, while the lay-ups are different (test case 10 has somewhat higher shear strengths). For both the lay-ups, the model predicts almost equal stresses for all the laminae under uniaxial σz. For example at initial failure under compressive σz the lamina stress field for both the lay-ups is σ1=-σ2=251MPaσ3=-572MPaτ12=τ13=τ23=0

Under a uniaxial τyz although laminae stress are different for the two lay-ups, the axial stresses are zero in all the laminae. Therefore, the shear strengths of both the laminates are determined by the shear strength of the material system in 1–2 and 2–3 planes which are only 40% different (57 MPa versus 90 MPa). This leads to a relatively isotropic behavior under τyz stress, and it explains why the two failure envelops are similar.

Figures 16 and 17 exhibit a slight local increase in the shear strength at the vicinity of the vertical axis (σz=0). When no through-the-thickness axial stress is applied, axial stresses (σ1,σ2, and σ3) are zero in all the laminae for both the lay-ups. Thus, rf in equation (33) is zero for all the lamina and one of the rS or rd is zero for 0° and 90° lamina. A small σz induces axial stresses in all the laminae, increasing rf, rd and rS for all the laminae. Thus, when σz is introduced one or two of the three terms in equation (33) increases from zero. This causes a change in the laminate’s behavior at the vicinity of σz=0 that in turn slightly alters the trend of shear strength versus σz.

sec.title: Case 12: Out-of-the plane stress–strain curves for (0deg/90deg)S IM7/8551-7 laminate
sec.p:
For this case, compressive σz versus εz, σz versus εx, and σz versus εy stress–strain curves are presented for (0deg/90deg)S laminate with σy=σx=0. The model parameters for this material system were taken from Case 10. Figure 18 presents the stress–strain responses for this loading condition. The predicted values of εx and εy are equal throughout. The stress–strain curves are linear only up to the initial failure, because in the present work through-the-thickness and axial responses of the material were considered to be linear. Beyond the initial failure, the exponential rule of equations (52) and (53) were employed to decrease the material moduli with strain, resulting in a nonlinear response of the laminate. The initial failure is predicted to occur at a compressive σz of 572 MPa. At this stress level both 0° and 90° laminae experience through-the-thickness shear failure of the matrix. The matrix failure and its mode were predicted via equations (9), (13), and (20). Predicted values of εx, εy, and εz at initial failure are 0.32%, 0.3%, and −5.7%, respectively. The final failure was predicted at σy=-673MPa, as the shear stiffness of the matrix decreased to zero. Figure 18.
Stress–strain responses of (90deg/0deg)2s IM7/8551-7 laminate under compressive through-the-thickness loading.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A new strain energy based failure theory with reasonable number of model parameters was developed for triaxial loading conditions. It was shown that the new theory can predict major features of composite laminates mechanical response.

In the exercise described in the present study, the stress–strain responses and failure stresses of eight composite specimens made from four different materials were predicted. Response to the loads imposed was seen to be a function of the composite material, ply configuration and stress path. In each case studied, the relative contribution of the longitudinal, transverse and shear strain energies to the overall strain energy was determined incrementally for the applied load. Using the incremental approach proposed by Sandhu allowed for the updating of material properties as necessary to achieve convergence of ply stress and strain. In this work curing residual stresses were neglected. These stresses can affect predicted initial and final failure strength, as well as post initial failure response for multidirectional laminates (Cases 7 to 12).

In some cases assumptions were made that might not be necessary when a more complete experimental data set becomes available. One of the pieces of information that should prove to be of particular use is the Poisson’s effect as a function of strain. The model incorporates strain dependent relationships between longitudinal and transverse strains which, depending on the predicted failure mechanism, may measurably affect the computed ultimate strengths. The relative contributions of the longitudinal, transverse and shear strain energy to the overall value are determined by three shape factors (m1, m2 and m6) which are material properties. In the analysis presented, the shape factors were all taken to be equal to one. Experimental data that will allow us to improve on this simplifying assumption will be available in the next phase of the study. We also assumed that, upon failure of an individual lamina, all load being carried by that lamina would be immediately redistributed to the remaining unfailed laminae. The failure model allows for two additional ply unloading mechanisms. Our studies have shown that these other assumptions of load transfer lead to different ultimate failure load predictions. Additional work needs to be done to identify the most appropriate load transfer mechanisms. Further, it has been assumed that no strain components can exceed the ultimate strain components measured during simple loading conditions. This assumption needs to be investigated.

An energy based failure criterion suitable for describing the behavior of laminated composites has been described. This method evaluates the nonlinear response to the applied load on each ply in the subject laminate. By combining the computed longitudinal, transverse and shear strain energies and then comparing the calculated values with those obtained from measurements made in laboratory tests on samples of simple configuration, the analyst is able to predict the onset and progression of failure in laminates of arbitrary thickness and ply configuration.
As will be seen from the comparative study in Kaddour and Hinton,26 the current method is unique in terms of its formulation of the failure criteria and its progressive damage analysis.

Comparison between the theoretical predictions of the model and experimental data is made in Doudican et al.27 Also a comparison is made in Kaddour and Hinton28 between the modified model reported in Doudican et al.27 and other models involved in the WWFE-II.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

def.p: area under uniaxial stress–strain curve
components of laminate extensional stiffness matrix
material constant that influences shear strength of a lamina
model parameter
components of laminate coupling matrix
coefficients that express the contribution of σz in resultant axial forces of a multidirectional laminate
components of laminate bending stiffness matrix
lamina tangent Young’s modulus
coefficients that express the contribution of σz in resultant bending moments of a multidirectional laminate
axial strain
lamina orientation angle in x-y-z coordinate system
lamina tangent shear modulus
engineering shear strain
total thickness of a laminate
stiffness reduction factor. Also refers to lamina number in a laminate
material constant that influences shear strength of a lamina
shape factor
resultant bending moments per unit length of laminate
resultant axial forces per unit length of laminate
total number of laminae in a laminate
lamina Poisson’s ratio
lamina strain energy
stiffness coefficient of lamina in local coordinate system
stiffness coefficient of lamina in global coordinate system
stiffness coefficient of lamina in global coordinate system, after corrected for the effect of the normal stress, σ3
angle between 2-3 and 2'-3' planes
energy ratio
load vector that is resulted from the normal to the plane axial stress, σz
axial stress
laminate stress vector: σ¯=<σx,σy,τxy>T
compliance coefficient of (unidirectional) lamina
mean axial stress of lamina in 2–3 plane
maximum shear stress of lamina in 2–3 plane
lamina thickness
shear stress
top and bottom z coordinates (z is normal to laminate’s plane) of the k-th lamina
material directions of a lamina (or unidirectional laminate)
transformed coordinate system of lamina defined to compute strain energy components. Axes 1 and 1' coincide.
compressive
maximum shear in 2–3 plane of a lamina
longitudinal (fiber) direction of lamina
longitudinal shear
mean axial stress in 2'-3' plane of a lamina
tensile
global coordinate directions
equivalent stress under multiaxial loading used to calculate tangent moduli
ultimate strength
value of a variable at initial failure
